description: First attested in 1622. From Italian ingraziare or Medieval Latin *ingratiatus, from Latin in grātiam (“for the favor of”).

verbs.description: ingratiate (third-person singular simple present ingratiates, present participle ingratiating, simple past and past participle ingratiated)

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To bring oneself into favour with someone by flattering or trying to please him or her.
examples: [H]e would pat the children on the head when he saw them on the stairs, and ingratiate himself with them as far as he dared.

entries.meaning: (followed by to) To recommend; to render easy or agreeable.
examples: What difficulty would it [the love of Christ] not ingratiate to us?
